title: RL33669
content: The National Security Agency (NSA) conducted a secret Terrorist Surveillance Program (TSP) leading to a national debate on its legality under the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA). The program involved warrantless surveillance of international communications involving individuals believed to be associated with al Qaeda. The Bush Administration defended the program citing constitutional and statutory support. The Terrorist Surveillance Act of 2006 was introduced by Senator Mitch McConnell to address the issue. Title II of the Terrorist Surveillance Act of 2006, along with other bills in Congress, addresses electronic surveillance programs for acquiring foreign intelligence and preventing terrorist threats. The Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act provides a framework for electronic surveillance and obtaining foreign intelligence information. The Bush Administration argued for the need for speed and agility in combating terrorism. The Bush Administration argued for the need for speed and agility in combating terrorism. Attorney General Gonzales advised that surveillance orders were issued to target international communications involving members of al Qaeda or associated terrorist organizations. All surveillance previously under the TSP will now be conducted with FISC approval. The President decided not to reauthorize the TSP when the current authorization expires. Intelligence Committees were briefed on the classified details of the FISC orders. Leahy and Senator Specter were briefed on the NSA program, which has faced legal challenges. A U.S. District Court judge ruled the program unconstitutional, citing violations of various laws and amendments. The decision has been appealed to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit. Sec. 3 of S. 3931 creates a new Title VII in FISA for electronic surveillance programs. The proposed changes to FISA under the Terrorist Surveillance Act of 2006 include provisions for electronic surveillance programs, allowing for immediate surveillance in cases of suspect activity and extended surveillance for gathering foreign intelligence information. The FISC would have jurisdiction to review and authorize these programs, with initial authorizations lasting up to 90 days and reauthorizations determined by the FISC.
